feed.title: Combined summary - Dealing with OP_IF and OP_NOTIF malleability

entry.title: Combined summary - Dealing with OP_IF and OP_NOTIF malleability
entry.summary: In the given context, there is a contradiction between defining one and zero as arrays of length one to avoid any possibility of mutation in transactions and the previous rule that states they should be minimally encoded. To resolve this issue, the proposed solution is to explicitly define that the IF/NOTIF argument must be either a zero-length array or a single byte 0x01. This would prevent any potential mutation of the transaction by changing the length of the array.The discussion on the bitcoin-dev mailing list revolves around the use of OP_0 and OP_PUSH opcodes for pushing data in Bitcoin scripts. It is suggested that only OP_0 and OP_1 should be used for pushing data, and not any other opcode. One of the participants suggests defining "IF/NOTIF argument must be either a zero-length array or a single byte 0x01" explicitly as it contradicts the rule of minimally-encoded "zero." The concern is to avoid any potential mutation of the transaction by changing the length of the array.On November 6, 2015, jl2012 proposed a new Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) for fixing malleability in OP_IF and OP_NOTIF. These codes are used in the Bitcoin script system to control program flow based on whether the top stake value is zero or not. The proposal specifies that if the transaction version is three or above, the flow control value for OP_IF and OP_NOTIF must be either zero or one, or else the transaction fails. This change should be implemented with BIP62, and it is a softfork.The proposal aims to make malleability of transactions with OP_IF and OP_NOTIF impossible and should be implemented alongside other malleability fixes. Transactions created before the introduction of this BIP will still be accepted by the network, and an OP_0NOTEQUAL could be used before the flow control code to transform any non-zero value to one for people who want to preserve the original behavior of OP_IF and OP_NOTIF.
